description: Private fire service main installation and testing

questions.question: What does NFPA 24 cover?
options: Private fire service mains and their appurtenances
questions.explanation: NFPA 24 covers the installation of private fire service mains and their appurtenances from the point of connection to the water supply to the base of the sprinkler riser.

questions.question: What pipe material is most commonly used for underground fire mains?
questions.explanation: Ductile iron pipe with cement lining is the most common material for underground fire mains due to its strength, corrosion resistance, and longevity.

questions.question: What is the minimum depth of cover for underground fire mains?
options: Below frost line and not less than code requirements
questions.explanation: Underground mains must be installed below the frost line to prevent freezing, and deep enough to protect against damage. Local codes specify minimums.

questions.question: What is a post indicator valve (PIV)?
options: An above-ground control valve with visual position indicator
questions.explanation: A post indicator valve is a gate valve with an above-ground post showing 'OPEN' or 'SHUT' to indicate valve position for fire protection water control.

questions.question: What is an OS&Y valve?
options: Outside Screw and Yoke indicating valve
questions.explanation: OS&Y (Outside Screw and Yoke) valves have an externally visible stem that shows valve position - stem out means open, stem in means closed.

questions.question: What is the purpose of a fire hydrant on private property?
options: Fire department access to private water supply
questions.explanation: Private fire hydrants provide fire department access to the property's water supply for firefighting operations, supplementing building fire protection systems.

questions.question: What is the minimum diameter for underground fire mains serving hydrants?
questions.explanation: Mains serving fire hydrants should generally be at least 6 inches in diameter, though larger sizes may be required based on demand calculations.

questions.question: What type of joint is common for ductile iron underground pipe?
options: Mechanical joint or push-on (bell and spigot)
questions.explanation: Mechanical joints and push-on joints are common for ductile iron pipe. They allow for easy assembly and some flexibility for ground movement.

questions.question: What testing is required for new underground fire mains?
questions.explanation: New underground mains require hydrostatic pressure testing at 200 psi for 2 hours (or higher pressure test) and thorough flushing before connection.

questions.question: What is the purpose of thrust blocks?
options: To restrain pipe at fittings against pressure thrust
questions.explanation: Thrust blocks are concrete supports placed at fittings (tees, bends, dead ends) to resist the thrust forces created by water pressure.

questions.question: What is a wall indicator valve (WIV)?
options: A valve installed through a wall with position indicator visible outside
questions.explanation: Wall indicator valves have a position indicator visible on the building exterior while the valve itself passes through the wall, controlling water to the system.

questions.question: What is the required flushing velocity for underground fire mains?
questions.explanation: Underground mains must be flushed at a minimum velocity of 10 fps to remove debris. Flow rate depends on pipe size to achieve this velocity.

questions.question: What is the significance of C-factor in underground pipe?
options: Hazen-Williams roughness coefficient affecting friction loss
questions.explanation: The C-factor in the Hazen-Williams formula represents pipe interior roughness. Lower C-values mean more friction loss. New cement-lined pipe is typically C=140.

questions.question: When are restrained joints required for underground pipe?
options: At fittings and locations of thrust where blocks are impractical
questions.explanation: Restrained joints mechanically connect pipe sections to resist thrust forces. They're required where thrust blocks cannot be installed or aren't practical.

questions.question: What is the spacing requirement for private fire hydrants?
options: As determined by fire department and code requirements
questions.explanation: Hydrant spacing is determined by fire department requirements, building codes, and occupancy hazards. Typical ranges are 300-500 feet maximum spacing.

questions.question: What backflow prevention is required on fire service connections?
options: As required by local water authority - typically double check or RPBA
questions.explanation: Backflow prevention requirements are set by the water authority. Double check assemblies or reduced pressure backflow assemblies are commonly required.

questions.question: What is required at the connection between underground and above-ground piping?
options: Support, wall seal, and protection from settlement and movement
questions.explanation: The underground to above-ground transition requires proper support, wall seals or sleeves, and provisions for differential settlement between pipe and structure.

questions.question: What is a looped water supply?
options: Piping connected to supply at both ends for redundancy
questions.explanation: A looped supply provides water from two directions, improving reliability and flow capacity. If one section is shut down, water still reaches the system.

questions.question: What color are private fire hydrants typically painted?
options: Red or as required by AHJ
questions.explanation: Private fire hydrants are often painted red (traditional) or colors designated by the authority having jurisdiction. Some systems color-code by flow capacity.

questions.question: What valve arrangement is required on fire hydrant laterals?
options: Gate valve (PIV or underground) for isolation
questions.explanation: Each hydrant lateral typically requires an isolation valve (post indicator or underground indicator) to allow hydrant maintenance without shutting down the main.

questions.question: What is a dry barrel hydrant?
options: A hydrant with no water connection
A hydrant where water is held below frost line until operated
questions.explanation: Dry barrel hydrants have the valve at the bottom below frost line. The barrel drains automatically when closed, preventing freezing.

questions.question: What thrust force calculation is required for underground fittings?
options: Thrust = Pressure Ã— Area of fitting opening
questions.explanation: Thrust force at fittings is calculated as pressure times the area of the pipe opening. This determines thrust block or restrained joint requirements.

questions.question: What is the flow test procedure for fire hydrants?
options: Static pressure, residual pressure at flow, and pitot readings
questions.explanation: Hydrant flow tests measure static pressure, then flowing one or more hydrants to get residual pressure and flow using pitot gauges to calculate available supply.

questions.question: What is cathodic protection for underground pipe?
options: Electrical protection against corrosion using sacrificial anodes or impressed current
questions.explanation: Cathodic protection prevents pipe corrosion by making the pipe the cathode of an electrochemical cell using sacrificial anodes or impressed current systems.

questions.question: When is polyethylene encasement required for ductile iron pipe?
options: In corrosive soils or as specified by design
questions.explanation: Polyethylene encasement (loose poly wrap) protects ductile iron pipe from corrosive soil conditions. Soil analysis determines the need.

questions.question: What is the acceptance test pressure for underground fire mains?
questions.explanation: New underground mains must be hydrostatically tested at 200 psi (or 50 psi above maximum system pressure if higher) for a minimum of 2 hours.

questions.question: What leakage is acceptable during hydrostatic testing of underground mains?
options: Allowance based on pipe size, length, and test pressure
questions.explanation: Some leakage is allowed, calculated based on pipe diameter, length, and test pressure. Formulas in NFPA 24 specify allowable leakage rates.

questions.question: What documentation is required for underground fire main installation?
options: Material certificates, test reports, as-built drawings
questions.explanation: Underground installations require material certifications, pressure test reports, flushing records, and accurate as-built drawings showing depths and locations.

questions.question: What is the minimum separation between fire mains and sanitary sewers?
options: 10 feet horizontal and 18 inches vertical typically
questions.explanation: Water mains must maintain separation from sewer lines to prevent contamination. Typical requirements are 10 feet horizontal and 18 inches vertical with water above.

questions.question: What is a wet barrel hydrant?
options: A hydrant with water always in the barrel (for warm climates)
A hydrant in a wet location
questions.explanation: Wet barrel hydrants have water up to each outlet with individual valves at each outlet. They're used only in areas without freezing temperatures.
